title.narrative: UNICEF maternal and child health support (MDG 4&5)

description.narrative:
Demokratiska Republiken Kongo (DRK) har en befolkning på över 70 miljoner människor spridda över 2 340 000 kvadratkilometer. Sjuttio procent av befolkningen bor på landsbygden. Den årliga befolkningstillväxten är 3,1 procent. Efter mer än ett decennium av väpnade konflikter har säkerhetsläget successivt förbättrats, men trots detta fanns det i augusti 2014 fortfarande över 2,6 miljoner interna flyktingar i östra delen av landet. FN har en fredsbevarande styrka (MONUSCO) på över 20 000 personer stationerade i landet. BNP per capita är 180 USD och mer än 70 procent av befolkningen lever under fattigdomsgränsen. Många hälsoindikatorer är alarmerande; av barnen lider 43 % av kronisk undernäring, 15 procent av kvinnorna i åldern 15-24 år vet inte hur HIV överförs, både mödra- och barnadödligheten är mycket höga. DRK kommer inte att lyckas uppfylla något av FN:s millennieutvecklingsmål fram till 2015.
I ljuset av ovan nämnda utvecklingsproblematik med betydande utmaningar inom hälsoområdet, har UNICEF ansökt till ambassaden om finansiering för genomförande av hälsokomponenten i deras Strategiska Plan 2014-2017 i Demokratiska Republiken Kongo.
Insatsens övergripande målsättning är att bidraga till förbättrade och mer jämlika hälsoinsatser som har hög påverkan på både mödra- och barnhälsan i DRK.
Stödet inkluderar hälsovårdssystemstärkande åtgärder och insatser för att påskynda att DRK når milleniemål 4 (barnhälsa) och milleniemål 5 (mödrahälsa).
UNICEF kommer att fokusera på att leverera mätbara resultat inom sex programområden:
1) Vaccinering 2) Polio 3) Barn- och mödrahälsa 4) Grundläggande barnhälsa (lunginflammation, diarré och malaria) 5) Stärkande av hälsosystem 6) förbättrade möjligheter att leverera hälsotjänster i humanitära situationer.
Hela insatsen förväntas leverera resultat inom sex målområden:
1. Ökat stöd till barn och föräldrar för att främja positiva hälsobeteenden; 2. Ökad nationell kapacitet för att öka tillgången till kraftfulla och effektiva barn- och mödravårdsinsatser; 3. Förstärkt politiskt engagemang, ansvarstagande för att lagstifta, planera, budgetera och följa upp hälsoinsatser; 4. Ökad kapacitet på landnivå för att kunna leverera hälsotjänster för att förhindra överdödlighet bland flickor, pojkar och kvinnor i humanitära situationer; 5. Ökad kapacitet hos regering och partners för att kunna identifiera och svara upp mot centrala mänskliga rättigheter och förstå jämställdhetsdimensioner av mödrars och barns hälsa; 6. Förstärkt global och regional kapacitet att förbättra barnhälsan.
Av ovan nämnda sex målområden har Ambassaden i sin kommunikation med UNICEF framfört att Sverige kommer att följa upp samtliga, fast med ett särskilt fokus på målområdena 2, 3 och 5.
Insatsen kommer att vara landsomfattande och nå alla 515 hälsozoner i samtliga av DRK:s 11 provinser. Genomförandet sker i nära koordination med hälsoministeriet i DRK och i samarbete med en rad av UNICEF:s partnerorganisationer.
Följande dokumentation ligger till grund för Ambassadens bedömning av det föreslagna stödet till UNICEF för 2014-2016 i DRK: 1) The UNICEF Strategic Plan 2014-2017 2) Final results framework of the UNICEF Strategic Plan, 2014-2017 3) Revised Supplementary Programme Note on the Theory of Change for the UNICEF Strategic Plan, 2014-2017 4) A Guide to UNICEF Thematic Funding 2014-2017 5) UNCIEF's Country Program Document for 2013-2017 6) UNICEF Country Programme Action Plan 2013-2017 7) Sidas centrala bedömning av UNICEF
Ambassaden föreslår att stötta UNICEF med ett tematiskt hälsostöd till UNICEF för 2014-2016 på 190 MSEK.
The program aims to increase the accessibility to effecient, effective and equitable basic health services to improve child- and maternal health in the DRC.

description.narrative: The overall expected outcome of this support was "improved and equitable use of high-impact maternal and child health interventions from pregnancy to adolescence and the promotion of healthy behaviours". In order to achieve this, Unicef has focused on delivering results in six programme areas, namely: Immunization; Polio; Maternal and new-born health; Child health (pneumonia, diarrhoea, and malaria); Strengthening health systems; and Health in humanitarian situations. The six outputs that will contribute to the overall outcome are:1. Enhanced support for children and caregivers, from pregnancy to adolescence, for improved healthy behaviours;2. Increased national capacity to provide access to essential high-impact maternal and child health interventions;3. Strengthened political commitment, accountability and national capacity to legislate, plan and budget for scaling up of health interventions;4. Increased country capacity and delivery of services to prevent excess mortality among girls, boys and women in humanitarian situations;5. Increased capacity of governments and partners, as duty-bearers, to identify and respond to key human rights and gender equality dimensions of maternal and child health; and6. Enhanced global and regional capacity to accelerate progress in child health.The Embassy made it clear to Unicef that in the monitoring and follow-up the Embassy would put a special attention to output 2, 3 and 5, as these outputs reflected some of the policy priorities of the Swedish government. A number of key achievements have been registered during the project's life time, in respective results areas: Result area 2: Overall, national vaccine coverage has remained practically unchanged during the last 5 years where the pentavalent3 vaccine oscillated between 74% and 81% from 2013 to 2016. In provinces supported by Unicef, use of innovate and equity-focused approaches to reinforce routine immunization starting in the second semester of 2015, proved that measles vaccination coverage could be improved in the provinces of Kinshasa, Ituri, and Tshopo from 77% to 91%, 86% to 98%, and from 86% to 93%, respectively from 2013 to 2017. In terms of equity, there are tremendous investments to be made. Indeed, 17% of health zones recorded less than 80% vaccine coverage. This indicates that several hundreds of children are still not reached. Other results include improvement management of the main killer diseases of under-5 children: The distribution of family kits and Integrated Community Case Management (iCCM) commodities, supported by Unicef was implemented in 1,756 community sites in 128 health zones and contributed to increase availability of essential drugs in households and health facilities as part of the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness (IMCI) approach to address diarrhoea, fever, pneumonia, and anaemia among children under-five (U5). The availability of Amoxycillin DT, ORS, and Zinc in 1,756 community care sites within 128 HZ resulted in the management of 85,635 cases of diarrhoea and 46,930 cases of pneumonia. In addition, 2,244,883 IMCI kits delivered to 1,321,472 children under-five contributed towards household treatment of simple cases of diarrhoea. The mosquito net distribution campaign reached 435,588 households in the Kasai Central province in 2017 alone, and contributed towards increasing effective use of long lasting insecticide nets (LLIN) among children under-five from 29% in 2013 (DHS) to 87% (HMIS) in 2017. Result areas 3 and 4 included interventions and broader partnerships aimed at strengthening the health systems. Unicef role is critical to reinforcement of the MoH institutions/programmes both centrally and in provinces in order for the sytems to be able to deliver health services, thus avoiding vertical and parallel solutions, and reaching even remote populations. Unicef has been key player in strengthening the new provincial health divisions (DPS) that have resulted from the recent creation of new province in DRC. Unicef contributed to improving coordination of partners (ie. 90% of GIBS meetings take place at Unicef) and supported planning and monitoring at the national and provincial levels, while generating evidence to support strategic planning and decision making. On strategy development, Unicef contributed to the development and adoption of (i) the National Strategic Plan for Essential Drugs, (ii) national procedures which establish a flat rate for health services, (iii) clinical mentoring programme tools, (iv) the Every New Born Action Plan, and (v) the National HIV Pediatric Plan. To ensure a regular monitoring of the effective coverage of high impact interventions at decentralized level, in 2017, all the 26 provinces have integrated programme monitoring to bi-annual revue at Provincial level. Other results areas (1) included the implementation of PMTCT programme, 1 063 pregnant women tested positive for HIV and initiated treatment and as part of the provincial action plans on HIV among adolescents 133,245 adolescents were sensitized on HIV in 2017 only. On a community level, the emphasis was on high impact interventions and on coverage of all poor vulnerable children and pregnant mothers. Vulnerable populations in targeted areas received a totally subsidized support, including kits for diarrhoea, micronutrients for children 12 months to 23 months, delivery kits for pregnant women and essential commodities for new-borns. The cost of this totals 0.69 USD per capita per year. The goal for Unicef and other donors has been to advocate for increased government's share in financing health in DRC, thus building sustainability to the health system. This is a long-term and continuous objective. Unicef has explored a model for subvention for transport for the children and mothers with complications who need referral to the district hospital.
